etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in John Evelyn (1620–1706), diarist and writer. Originally from classical Latin fūnambulus funambulus

definitions: A person who walks or performs on a rope stretched between two points at some height above the ground; a tightrope walker; a funambulist.

notes.text: In later use only in French contexts and chiefly with reference to Philippe Petit, who in 1974 walked on a tightrope stretched between the twin towers of the World Trade Centre in New York.
